title: Tiger Global gets mauled by the bear market
text:
One thing to start: Intercontinental Exchange has deepened its push into the US housing market data business, striking the largest deal in its history by agreeing to purchase mortgage software company Black Knight for $13.1bn.

Has Tiger Global lost the plot?

Chase Coleman has shown little interest in changing his stripes.

The descendant of Julian Robertson's Tiger Management clawed out from behind the shadow of his legendary former boss to launch the largest and most successful hedge fund of any of his fellow “Tiger Cubs”.

Coleman's Tiger Global borrows from Robertson's signature long-short playbook, placing big bets on tech and shorting underperforming stocks.

Like his mentor, Coleman positioned himself as a master stockpicker, prioritising long-term potential over valuations and yielding huge gains from stocks often considered expensive by traditional valuation metrics. He has built a huge private tech investing business with a similar ethos.

The move-fast-and-break-things approach — piling into high-growth tech stocks while successfully shorting the losers — panned out particularly well in the coronavirus pandemic bull market. But times have changed.

Tiger Global's flagship hedge fund lost 15.2 per cent in April, a person familiar with the matter told the FT, and is down more than 40 per cent so far this year — one of the worst drawdowns in hedge fund history, Alphaville notes.

“April added to a very disappointing start to 2022 for our public funds. Markets have not been co-operative given the macroeconomic backdrop, but we do not believe in excuses and so will not offer any,” the firm's investment team wrote in a letter to investors seen by the FT, adding that it would continue to manage the portfolio as described in its Q1 letter.

Coleman sticking to his guns shouldn't come as a surprise to investors. “Tiger is long tech. That is their job. If you don't want to be long tech, don't own Tiger,” one Tiger Global investor told DD's Antoine Gara.

A bottleneck in the IPO pipeline — brought on by increased market volatility, lacklustre IPO performances and the fizzling Spac frenzy — has also taken a toll.

Tiger's fall from grace reminds DD of a similar case last year when Melvin Capital, which runs a pretty aggressive short book, suffered heavy losses after betting against meme-stock darling Gamestop.

The fallout was so bad that founder Gabe Plotkin's old boss Steve Cohen and Citadel's Ken Griffin stepped in with a capital infusion to save the day. But things haven't gotten any better. Melvin has lost a further 20.6 per cent in the first quarter of this year.

Coleman and Plotkin are both facing a dilemma that even their most deep-pocketed allies can't fix: performance fee structures.

Hedge funds have long maintained so-called high-water marks, which prohibit them from charging performance fees until losses have been recovered. Last month, Plotkin backpedalled on his own efforts to change the rules after facing searing investor backlash.

Without the broader tech market on its side, it'll be difficult for Tiger Global to stage a comeback any time soon — let alone start charging performance fees again.

The ex-KKR dealmaker waging a campaign on a K-Pop machine

Activists have historically held little sway in South Korea.

The industry has long been viewed there as predatory foreign funds engaging in what is known locally as “eat and run”. 

After campaigning against a contentious merger in 2015 of Samsung's construction and chemicals subsidiaries, Elliott Management was berated in the press as a “parasite”. Its founder, Paul Singer, was caricatured on Samsung C&T's website as a bespectacled vulture.

Thirty-five-year old Changhwan Lee, who left KKR last year to set up his own activist fund in Seoul, sees an opening for change.

“Everyone in the Korean stock market is frustrated by local companies not realising their value because of poor governance,” he told the FT's Christian Davies. “It's been like that for 20 years.”

For months, the millennial activist has been waging a campaign to improve governance at SM Entertainment, the publicly traded K-pop factory behind popular artists including singer/songwriter Ryeowook and rapper Taeyong.

Lee's Align Partners, which holds a 0.9 per cent stake in SM and has just $65mn in assets under management, successfully campaigned for an independent auditor on SME's board — a decisive victory against the company's founder and controlling shareholder Soo-man “SM” Lee, who has stacked the music group's board with relatives, childhood friends and other allies.

It's an important win for activists in Korea Inc., where corporate behemoths including Samsung and Hyundai operate without much interference. A bigger change will come, according to Lee, when the country's growing army of retail investors begins to leverage its power over the market.

Aston Martin puts a new driver in the hot seat

The hardest part of keeping the James Bond franchise alive is changing the lead.

Aston Martin, whose sleek models saturated the Craig-era flicks, has a similar quandary.

The luxury carmaker abruptly parted ways with chief executive Tobias Moers on Wednesday, with the former Mercedes engineer making way for one-time boss of Ferrari, Amedeo Felisa, the FT's Peter Campbell reports.

Lawrence Stroll, the company's chair and owner, decried that the change was needed for the next chapter in a turnround that he hopes will rekindle Aston's fortunes and bring it within touching distance of Ferrari as a hallmark for luxury motoring.

But Moers' departure has been brewing for months, if not longer, and is largely down to the robust management style of the German.

Dozens of senior executives have left the business during Moers' two years at the helm, high churn even by the standards of the most rigorous corporate turnround.

Stroll was forced to deny in January that he planned to switch out Moers, after the undercurrent of rumours broke the surface.

At a private dinner between the pair the following week, Stroll told Moers to improve morale in the business that had fallen to near-rock bottom. Things improved, but the damage was done.

The biggest question is how long 76-year-old Felisa, who ran Ferrari until 2016, plans to stay.

Coupled with the announcement was a set of first-quarter results that reminded investors of the long road ahead. Pre-tax losses mounted after depreciation of investments into older cars, while payments on its high-interest debt continue to sap what profitability is left.

For all its Bondian sheen, Felisa is taking hold of a business that is brittle. Try to bring it back in one piece.

Job moves

  • JPMorgan Chase has promoted Jeremy Capstick to global co-head of market infrastructure. Additionally, Aviva's former chief strategy and M&A officer Chetan Singh is rejoining the firm in June to take over from him as co-head of FIG for Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

  • Eversheds Sutherland has named Linklaters veteran Roger Barron as a senior M&A adviser to its corporate unit. He was most recently global vice chair of Paul Hastings.

  • Boutique investment bank LionTree has hired Andrew Olinick, co-head of North America private equity at London-headquartered 3i, as a managing partner, per Bloomberg.

  • Orrick has named Pete Sugden as a partner focused on venture capital, M&A and private equity, based in London. He joins from Reynolds Porter Chamberlain.

Smart reads 

Phone a friend While his fellow oligarchs mingled with western power brokers and splurged on luxury properties, Andrey Kosogov floated under the radar. Until his sanctioned peers needed someone to manage their fortunes, Bloomberg reports.

Still buffering Sony's strategy as an entertainment “arms dealer” has helped it scrape by as cost-conscious households turn on Netflix and other subscription services. But the Japanese group's own margins could be at risk if more consolidation ensues, the FT's Leo Lewis writes.

Crypto campaign trail Digital currencies were the big winners in the Ohio Senate primary, as politicians on both sides of the aisle aligned themselves with lighter regulations surrounding the polarising asset class, Politico reports.
